questions.question_text: An engineer is deploying Cisco ISE to use 802.1X authentication for controlling access to the company's wired network. The request from company management is to minimize the impact on users during the rollout of 802.1X on the company switches. Which mode must be used first in a phased 802.1X deployment to fulfill this request?

comments.content: The question requested the MODE & there's no such thing as Open mode. There are three modes Monitor, Low-Impact and Closed.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B, monitor is just a description for what open mode is.
there is no actual monitor mode

Selected Answer: A
A is correct

comments.content:
We recommend monitor mode as a first-phase approach to provide secure access with IEEE 802.1x.
Although this mode authenticates the end devices and users (supplicants), traffic is not impacted if
authentication fails

discussion.content:
I agree with thol119:

Although this mode authenticates the end devices and users (supplicants), traffic is not impacted if
authentication fails.
In monitor mode, IEEE 802.1x and MAB are enabled, but access is open to all users.

To allow hosts to gain access to a controlled port, configure multi-authentication host mode and open
authentication. 
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst3850/software/release/16-1/best_practices_guide/BP_Cat3850/BP_wired_security.pdf

Selected Answer: A
A. First phase is a 802.1x deployment is monitr mode.

questions.question_text:
//IMG//
Refer to the exhibit. Which checkbox must be enabled to allow Cisco ISE to publish group membership information for active users that can be shared with Cisco Firepower devices?

choices.A: Use the captive portal network assistant to issue certificates to the endpoints as they authenticate.
choices.B: Use ISE as a sub CA for the BYOD portal and redirect users to the Root CA for certificate issuance.
choices.D: Configure MS SCEP so that endpoints can query their local AD server for the correct certificate.
choices.C: Configure the Cisco ISE Internal CA to issue certificates to each endpoint connecting to the BYOD network.

discussion.content:
PKI and ISE Internal CA
Although issuing signed certificates to the endpoints for BYOD is optional, many customers will consider issuing certificates to the endpoints as it provides better security and user experience for subsequent connections. When ISE is installed the internal CA is installed and enabled by default. Here are the characteristics of ISE internal CA.

- Primary Admin node is the root CA

- Both primary and Secondary admin node is also Sub-CA of the root called Node_CA. This added layer of hierarchy allows single root hierarchy which simplifies the deployment when new PSNs are added while the primary node is not the active admin node

questions.question_text: To configure BYOD using Cisco ISE. an administrator is considering issuing certificates to the devices connecting to provide a better user experience. External CA servers cannot be used for this purpose because everything must be local to the Cisco ISE. What must be done to accomplish this?

choices.A: Set Promiscuous mode to inherit from vSwitch in the Port Group properties.
choices.B: Set Promiscuous mode to inherit from Port Group in the vSwitch properties.
choices.D: Set Promiscuous mode to Accept in the vSwitch properties.
choices.C: Set Promiscuous mode to Accept in the Port Group properties.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Tested today in a lab, 327c7c8 is right. The crux is indeed on vSwitch permissions. The sentence “provides access to the Cisco ISE VM and the network settings” is the crux in this query . The example in the book does not take this into account

Selected Answer: D
D should be the answer:

Chapter 14 profiling page 427 Ciscopress 300-715.
"In order to use SPAN probes with ISE , you need to configure a vSwitch to allow promiscuous connections"

comments.content:
The engineer is logged into the hypervisor with a user account that only provides access to the Cisco ISE VM and the network settings for the VM
that is way C is the correct answer. tricky question, I saw the OCG it is stating vSwitch but the user dose not have access to it .

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is correct. Has to be done at the port-group level. https://kb.vmware.com/s/article/1004099

Selected Answer: C
In VMWare Promiscious mode can be specified at the portgroup level or vSwitch level, it does not inherit.
If the user does not have access to all settings then it must be port group, as vSwitch is global settings.
